data.text: (THREAD) How globalisation affects inflation and financing conditions in the euro area depends on our policy response, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. The euro area has monetary autonomy – the question is how to use it wisely. Speech https://t.co/xLZ5UN0D09 1/5 https://t.co/LhbD0adnwc
Working Paper: Tracking global economic uncertainty - Implications for the euro area https://t.co/7FLQBaiTPb
Working Paper: Foreign banks and the doom loop https://t.co/Je0W32LPW8

Are you a PhD student in economics or finance interested in sharing your research at the #ECBForum and winning €10,000? Then enter our young economists’ competition by 30 May. More details here https://t.co/mAQr5aDeUT https://t.co/Zans2XSnqp
Watch again: President @Lagarde responds to criticism about negative interest rates and describes how they support companies and people in the eurozone https://t.co/kHcRbKisl5
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Gunnar Beck, MEP, on ECB communication https://t.co/AXeWYoCKj8
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Engin Eroglu, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/FK1xgL3Eqt (EN) https://t.co/5kM1nyw2Nx (DE)
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Ernest Urtasun, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/Scy9OTUjRk
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Gunnar Beck, MEP, on the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices https://t.co/jN41S0x4Wr
TARGET2-Securities Annual Report 2020 https://t.co/u4S7JjAcBX
Working Paper: Capital flows-at-risk - Push, pull and the role of policy https://t.co/W2iA2IhPfD
Working Paper: Leveraged property cycles https://t.co/tZMryg6mk0
Results of the ECB Survey of Professional Forecasters in the second quarter of 2021 https://t.co/R70ObVVTQQ
US dollar liquidity-providing operations from 1 July 2021 https://t.co/1S6Qds4QH6

Businesses tell the ECB that pandemic-related restrictions and supply issues prevent them from replying to strong or growing demand. While selling prices are increasing for manufactured goods, those for services remain subdued. Read more https://t.co/9Ycx4n2e9a #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/0tbS7eiPDY
Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s monetary policy press conference https://t.co/LSSGnzmp8p https://t.co/G5hNNI1dd0
Watch again: President @Lagarde on our pledge to keep financing conditions favourable https://t.co/qFhZCKNOgJ
What would you like to ask Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel? Post your question using #AskECB and follow her answers live on Wednesday, 28 April! https://t.co/KIXFIVdXtu
Introductory statement by President Christine @Lagarde to the press conference https://t.co/LSSGnzmp8p
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Christine @Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/1ws7o4VOXE
Coming up in 15 minutes: watch live as President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/kP8v8VuE3A
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine @Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/BCbCd8E35n

We are looking for supervision analysts across our banking supervision areas.

Do you have a background in business, economics, IT, computer science, mathematics or physics?

Apply here by 12 May https://t.co/9pDa4Ni99i https://t.co/N5CsI4scei
We asked 143 banks in the euro area about changes in their lending behaviour and loan demand during the first quarter of 2021. Find out the results https://t.co/A0fz7RdExb https://t.co/Zzgvpe0Td3

We carried out a large-scale review of internal models checking that banks comply with the rules and implement these models consistently. Find out more about the exercise and our findings.
Press release https://t.co/EzFqF1fJuB
Internal models https://t.co/41LjH8ceqB https://t.co/AB6i9No9uX
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Feb 2021) https://t.co/SnrJRs0o1w
@daniell_andrei Thank you for spotting. We have corrected the link.
Research bulletin: Making waves – Fed spillovers are stronger and more encompassing than the ECB’s https://t.co/KPr5IdyI04

(For German speakers) Register now and follow live from 19:00 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel will discuss our monetary policy with member of the @Europarl_EN @Sven_Giegold in a webinar organised by @SVR_Wirtschaft https://t.co/OS0pFy377o https://t.co/SWUWhR5h8L https://t.co/Z7VnLkTgf2

Did you miss it? You can still watch Executive Board member Fabio Panetta talking about the outcome of the public consultation on a digital euro at the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs @EP_Economics https://t.co/SkamHnaGuA https://t.co/k9o5XWNUny

Do liquidity policy measures hurt fund investors? Our latest Macroprudential Bulletin shows that pre-emptive liquidity measures make funds more resilient and investors safer, especially when market liquidity is low. Read more https://t.co/XVgv41BJLr https://t.co/mUfteF5QNA

Panetta: Responses to the public consultation show the high expectations that people have for a digital euro. They will provide valuable input for our work and decision on whether to start a digital euro project. We will move rapidly but take the time to do it right 3/3

Panetta: Protecting privacy will be a priority so that the digital euro helps maintain trust in digital payments. Our preliminary experimentation shows how technology can be used to protect privacy without relaxing standards against illicit activities https://t.co/1KUR7ba3Bq 2/3

(THREAD) The record participation in our public consultation and willingness of citizens and professionals to support a digital euro are encouraging. The most valued features are privacy, security and broad usability. Speech https://t.co/YO6QNjT8sN 1/3 https://t.co/dOT1WgQjCj

Coming up at 13:45 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta will present the outcome of the public consultation on a digital euro at the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs @EP_Economics.
Follow live https://t.co/SkamHnaGuA

Fiscal, monetary and supervisory authorities have reduced the economic and social costs of the crisis. They face a delicate balancing act between the risk of withdrawing measures too early and keeping them in place for too long.

We saw the largest economic contraction recorded in post-war history in 2020. Uncertainty remains high, but thanks to vaccinations, the easing of confinement measures and fiscal and monetary support the economy should pick up strongly in the second half of 2021.

Last year has been exceptionally challenging for all of us, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos as he presents our Annual Report to the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee @EP_Economics 
https://t.co/8uZz4RJWlT
https://t.co/6qzBg7GWwd https://t.co/IPoaY60ec8

Our Annual Report for 2020 is now available in 22 languages @EP_Economics
https://t.co/gOeEZtkhFf https://t.co/ILpG5nOKlJ

Watch live from 09:00 CET: Vice-President Luis de Guindos presents our Annual Report 2020 to the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee @EP_Economics. He will also discuss the current economic outlook and road to recovery https://t.co/Dxa9TqcbVq https://t.co/69PKjoAusm

We received more than 8,000 replies to our public consultation on a digital euro, mostly from citizens and the rest from businesses and professionals in the payments sector. 
Have a look at their views https://t.co/enbOpUWFfl

Privacy is the most important feature of a #digitaleuro for both citizens and professionals, with security and the ability to pay across the euro area close behind. Respondents want innovative services integrated into existing payment systems. https://t.co/4isT5AcL9c

Many European investment funds stopped investors withdrawing capital during the market turmoil at the onset of the pandemic. What made them do this and how can such a move affect the wider financial system? Read more in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/WroC61wXsY https://t.co/JTfULUYRgL
Working paper: The interplay between green policy, electricity prices, financial constraints and jobs - firm-level evidence https://t.co/GVfh6jQTUO

How effective is the EU Money Market Fund Regulation? Market events in March 2020 tested the strength of the money market fund sector, raising questions about the regulation’s ability to tackle systemic risks. Read more in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/lzmjoon1bB https://t.co/CoiZGWnrIm

Europe needs to keep combatting the pandemic, President Christine @Lagarde tells @CNBCClosingBell. The ECB can expand its measures if needed, however pressing on with the recovery fund and vaccinations is now top priority. Read the full interview https://t.co/sh4SWqw6Q3 https://t.co/Cw4L65lPHB
Working paper: International medium-term business cycles https://t.co/dajNl4ICcw
Working paper: Euro area equity risk premia and monetary policy: a longer-term perspective https://t.co/50CFnMDL19

How did money market and investment funds react to the market turmoil at the start of the coronavirus pandemic? What made them vulnerable and how can policy strengthen their resilience? Find out in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/701e5jL5u0 https://t.co/qhGuixFYsz

Panetta: In the coming months we will decide whether to start investigating a digital euro – a form of money backed up by the ECB that allows Europeans to make secure digital payments. We could be ready to launch a digital euro within five years 3/3

Panetta: The pandemic has affected each country differently, but there has been a strong common European response. The EU recovery plan could serve as a prototype for a future common fiscal instrument 2/3

(THREAD) We need to be more ambitious and provide certainty about the European economy to help economic activity reach its full potential and ensure that inflation converges towards our aim, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta to @el_pais https://t.co/ryqF7sLomq 1/3 https://t.co/0t9aSx3vZC
Working Paper: The identification of dominant macroeconomic drivers - Coping with confounding shocks https://t.co/hiGLmKvzfx
Working Paper: Technology and demand drivers of productivity dynamics in developed and emerging market economies https://t.co/dvUuNh2Ma1
Households and non-financial corporations in the euro area (Q4 2020) https://t.co/CQeaqYXu6G
Euro area quarterly balance of payments and international investment position (Q4 2020) https://t.co/RR6XfoKku1
Also available in German https://t.co/7xQJ649VXr

A sustainable rise in inflation towards our aim would be good news as it would mean that the economy is gaining momentum, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells @derspiegel. The current increase is mostly due to one-off effects. Full interview https://t.co/Lxgr9RV1sW https://t.co/kpQbYKmEx1

One month ago President Christine @Lagarde and @EU_Commission President Ursula @vonderLeyen spoke about female leadership and fighting biases in #TheECBPodcast. 

Missed the episode? Listen here https://t.co/fIIRD13FEF https://t.co/v1AYnwUH1N https://t.co/AHZB1NoYUU
Account of the monetary policy meeting of the Governing Council of the ECB of 10-11 March 2021 https://t.co/YkkEEBGyBt
Euro money market statistics (First maintenance period 2021) https://t.co/82bUmNZKeh

EU rules require banks to maintain enough capital to cover unexpected losses. A bank can use a standardised approach or its own internal models to calculate this capital requirement. We explain how this works and how we supervise banks’ internal models https://t.co/Xi5kP4GDEG https://t.co/IyriTxxt8v

Lane: Offsetting the negative shock to inflation is only the first stage of the monetary policy challenge. Even after disinflationary pressures have been sufficiently offset, we will have to ensure timely and robust convergence to our inflation aim over the medium term. 3/3

Lane: The increase in inflation during 2021 can be best interpreted as the unwinding of disinflationary forces that took hold in 2020. It does not constitute the basis for a sustained shift in inflation dynamics 2/3

(THREAD) The recent volatility of inflation can be largely attributed to the nature of the pandemic shock, writes Chief Economist Philip R. Lane on #TheECBBlog.

Read his blog post https://t.co/G1mVYI15WU 1/3 https://t.co/6LppEEycdN

How has the euro short-term rate €STR performed since its introduction?

Discover this and more in our insights released on the euro area statistics website, available in 23 EU languages https://t.co/xfBOD3MTXV https://t.co/5ZmeCGAVz8
Euro area pension fund statistics (Q4 2020) https://t.co/KeitqeWycA
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Feb 2021) https://t.co/8oqpNH9G1j

Targeted longer-term refinancing operations encourage banks to keep credit flowing to people and businesses and keep their borrowing costs low. This, in turn, supports spending and investment in the economy. Check out our explainer to find out more https://t.co/xUD5k1kuvV https://t.co/KGpeVQDruP

Tonight, we join the rest of the #Frankfurt skyline for #EarthHour 2021 to raise awareness of the fight against climate change. 

➡️ Check out what else we do to tackle climate change https://t.co/I7pk4eDaJU
➡️ Find out more about Earth Hour https://t.co/buyjHc9Ph8 https://t.co/LgCixd2ZD9

Lane: Complementing our accommodative monetary policy, fiscal policy needs to counter the pandemic shock to incomes and the productive capacity of firms. It needs to ensure that overall demand conditions promote a timely recovery and underpin medium-term growth prospects 3/3

Lane: Shorter-term and longer-term economic performance are inextricably linked, especially in the current circumstances. A sustained period of below-capacity economic activity damages the longer-term level of potential output 2/3

(Thread) Our commitment to preserving favourable financing conditions acts as a stabilising force and boosts confidence, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. It counters the risks of self-fulfilling adverse dynamics that may affect the economic outlook https://t.co/QqPp1XKGBl 1/3 https://t.co/Bn6bsmJgrP
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/jFXpmxVsQS
Letter from the ECB President to Ms Julie Lechanteux, MEP, on the international role of the euro https://t.co/4IB6jheACB (EN) https://t.co/w00N2fjrfp (FR)
Letter from the ECB President to Ms Aurore Lalucq, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/sp7Q0sVU4M (EN) https://t.co/0BXW5N9DYr (FR)
Letter from the ECB President to Ms Julie Lechanteux, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/nHaXWazkGJ (EN) https://t.co/CgPGxBEPd6 (FR)
Letter from the ECB President to several MEPs, on climate change https://t.co/AZbnT1vuQm
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Martin Hojsík, Ms Sirpa Pietikäinen, Mr Paul Tang, Mr Gilles Boyer, Mr Pascal Canfin, Mr Bas Eickhout, MEPs, on climate change https://t.co/qoifQS09RX

Our decision to step up monthly emergency purchases is based on a thorough assessment of the drivers of recent yield increases, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. There was a risk of an abrupt and premature withdrawal of vital policy support https://t.co/jajKcJiVBl https://t.co/Gd4PSDwJUy

More attention should be paid to the stability risks if the ECB does not offer a digital currency. Preparing for a digital euro protects Europe’s autonomy. We must ensure our single currency is future-proof and fit for the digital age. Read more https://t.co/UMqavtJwC0 3/3

A digital euro would complement cash, not replace it. It would respect privacy, be available free of charge and facilitate secure digital payments in all corners of the euro area, backed by the commitment of an independent central bank to ensure its stability 2/3

(THREAD) At the ECB we are committed to understanding people’s needs and ensuring the digital euro would be widely accepted, writes Executive Board member Fabio Panetta with Ulrich Bindseil in The ECB Blog https://t.co/UMqavtJwC0 1/3 https://t.co/8nhLwFrWjA

The new 2021 Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices weights show major shifts, with recreation and transport decreasing the most and food items and housing increasing the most. These drove headline and core inflation upwards in January https://t.co/pwGTqLKTku #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/NT4nz1KByU

Industry, as well as countries such as Germany, also saw major effects during the start of the pandemic. They largely recovered during the second half of 2020, however, as economic agents learned to cope with containment measures https://t.co/WXKfWp4dyD #EconomicBulletin 2/2

How have containment measures hit different sectors and countries? Recreational services and countries such as Spain have been hit more heavily, and the effects of these measures are expected to continue in the short term. #EconomicBulletin 1/2 https://t.co/9pbTKvoqlO

Excess liquidity in the euro area rose further due to purchase programmes and recent targeted measures (TLTROs). Government deposits fell from record levels, and will continue to be affected by pandemic-related uncertainties.  Read more https://t.co/rS7vH44fu7 #EconomicBulletin

The euro area saw stricter lockdowns, lower inflation and a bigger drop in economic activity than the US last year, where fiscal policy support was stronger overall but less supportive to jobs. Read more https://t.co/Dz4zu5obBK #EconomicBulletin
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in February? How do they compare with January’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/3edV452bKm https://t.co/BdeRJ81uAz

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/wFXTLIMZBo https://t.co/CHUL40k4vn
Congrats to our ECB colleagues who co-authored the working paper winning the award! Here's the link https://t.co/gVRqyltzzH https://t.co/ESuzZ4L6gG

Our Chief Economist Philip R. Lane recently spoke with students from University College Dublin’s Economics Society.

He reflected on the current pandemic and offered advice for those interested in a career in economics.

Watch the interview https://t.co/2hgoPT0hGD https://t.co/qO4VBiqOYq

While corporate sector profits fell during the crisis, profit margins have been particularly resilient relative to the depth of the recession. Job retention schemes likely played an important role in making this so. Read more https://t.co/JUNvIKNT5b #EconomicBulletin

Economic inequality has risen in recent decades, primarily due to globalisation and technological developments. Monetary policy has played only a minor role, and in fact has dampened it by encouraging job creation. Read more https://t.co/1juHUnbfkj #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/5m5JT8OlLv

How does the coronavirus pandemic affect our economy? And what is the outlook for the coming months? Director General Economics Frank Smets discussed these topics with civil society representatives last week. Watch the full event here https://t.co/705IqMRlME.

Lane: As the recent US stimulus gets rolled out, it will be a significant engine for the world economy.

It will boost global GDP and boost exports from the euro area.

Read the transcript of the interview https://t.co/2eDsqXfHQ6 3/3

Lane: Our latest projections allow for some extension of lockdowns into the second quarter. The real concern is the underlying battle with the virus.

The risk of lockdowns will remain until the virus is more contained and until we have progress on vaccinations 2/3

(THREAD) We are committed to a substantial increase in the pace of purchasing, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @CNBC in an interview.

He adds that weekly data on our purchases should not be examined in isolation but rather averaged over several weeks 1/3 https://t.co/bwKbH7wuoY

The EU recovery package can contribute to a faster, stronger and more uniform recovery of our economy. This requires a balance of mutually reinforcing investments and reforms, increasing administrative capacity and reducing bottlenecks https://t.co/4DFK8OlDnY #EconomicBulletin

Why do consumers sometimes overestimate inflation? This is down to their uncertainty: those who aren’t certain tend to round up, and their expectations tend to be higher than actual inflation. This is made worse during crisis periods. https://t.co/6XjJrwNh7t #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/GSw504xvsr
